results.title: The Rutherford atom
results.creator_credit: Quentin Brown, Kevin Smith, Educational Services Incorporated and Physical Sciences Study Committee
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
A cloud chamber and gold foil in a simple alpha-particle scattering experiment illustrates the historic Rutherford experiment which led to the nuclear model of the atom. Behaviour of alpha particles clarified by use of large scale models illustrating the nuclear atom and Coulomb scattering.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Quentin Brown, Kevin Smith, Educational Services Incorporated and Physical Sciences Study Committee

results.title: Forces
results.creator_credit: Tarquin Cardona, Bob Starner, Olga Palacio, First Light Pictures and Schlessinger Media
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Physical science in action”.
There are many forces at work shaping our world every moment of our lives. This video describes Newton’s laws (first, second and third), friction, gravity, air and water pressure, and electromagnetism. Also explored is the concept of unbalanced forces. Suitable for Upper primary/lower secondary students. Teachers notes included.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tarquin Cardona, Bob Starner, Olga Palacio, First Light Pictures and Schlessinger Media

results.title: The Interference of photons
results.creator_credit: Educational Services Incorporated and Physical Sciences Study Committee
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Presents an experiment at MIT in which light exhibits both particle and wave characteristics. Characteristic interference pattern is pointed out by many individual photons hitting at places consistent with the interference pattern.

results.title: Sound waves in air
results.creator_credit: Quentin Brown, Kevin Smith and Educational Services, Inc.
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Investigates wave characteristics of sound transmission with large-scale equipment, using frequencies up to 5000 cycles. Experiments in reflection, diffraction, interference and refraction are supplemented by ripple-tank analogies. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Quentin Brown, Kevin Smith and Educational Services, Inc.

results.title: Frames of reference
results.creator_credit: Richard Leacock, Kevin Smith, Stephen White and Educational Services Incorporated Film Division
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Demonstrates the changes in observed motion of a freely falling body viewed from differently moving frames of reference. Donald Ivey and Patterson Hume discuss relative motion, accelerated and inertial frames of reference, and show the inadequacy of Newtonian physics, calling for calculation of fictitious forces to describe relative motions.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Leacock, Kevin Smith, Stephen White and Educational Services Incorporated Film Division

results.title: Inertia
results.creator_credit: Educational Services and Physical Sciences Study Committee
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Edward M. Purcell demonstrates Galileo’s principle of inertia in experiments with a body moving horizontally with minimal friction and using low friction dry-ice pucks and multiple flash photography showing acceleration is proportional to force when mass is constant. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Millikan experiment
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Simplified experiment substituting standard spheres for oil drops; analysis of the charge related to the velocity of the sphere across field of view of microscope emphasises the evidence that charge comes in natural units that are all alike; numerous changes of charge are shown, produced by X-rays.
results.description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.

results.title: Vector kinematics
results.creator_credit: Jack Churchill, Kevin Smith and Educational Services Incorporated
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”
Displacement, velocity and acceleration vectors are demonstrated for circular, simple harmonic and other two-dimensional motions, displayed visually on a cathode ray tube screen by an electronic computer. Francis L. Friedman discusses their relationships.

results.title: Behavior of gases
results.creator_credit: Gene Kearney, John Friedman, Lee Grodzins and Educational Services Incorporated
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
The Brownian motion as applicable to smoke particles is shown by photomicrography and compared with a mechanical analogue. Animation is used to develop a model for gas pressure based on chaotic molecular motion. This chaotic motion is contrasted with the orderly behaviour of gases as shown by an experiment illustrating Boyle’s Law. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gene Kearney, John Friedman, Lee Grodzins and Educational Services Incorporated

This chaotic motion is contrasted with the orderly behaviour of gases as shown by an experiment illustrating Boyle’s Law. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Elastic collisions and stored energy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Demonstrates the concept of stored energy. Uses the example of collisions between two dry-ice pucks. Cylindrical magnets are mounted on the pucks, producing a repelling force, and the kinetic energy of the pucks is measured. Suitable for upper secondary level.
